questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?

answers.query: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?

evaluation.answer: Based on the provided constitutional context, the theft of a car would fall under the domain of 'Criminal law.' The Indian Constitution's Seventh Schedule, under List III (Concurrent List), explicitly includes 'Criminal law' as a subject for legislative action, meaning it is a matter addressed by legal statutes and courts.

32. Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part.‚Äî(1)

evaluation.answer: Yes, an arrest without a warrant can be legal under the Constitution of India. It stipulates that any person arrested and detained must be produced before the nearest magistrate within twenty-four hours, excluding travel time, and further detention requires a magistrate's authority. Additionally, provisions exist for preventive detention without a warrant, governed by specific laws enacted by Parliament.

evaluation.answer: No, denying a job to someone based on their caste is not allowed under The Constitution of India. Article 16 (2) guarantees equality of opportunity in public employment and explicitly states that no citizen shall be discriminated against on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence, or any of them, in respect of any employment or office under the State.

evaluation.answer: No, you generally cannot stop the government from taking your land for a project if it is for public purposes and is carried out in accordance with existing law. The Constitution of India allows for the compulsory acquisition of land by the State for public purposes, and laws authorizing such acquisition are explicitly protected from being deemed void on the grounds of inconsistency with certain fundamental rights.

evaluation.answer: No, it is not legal for a child to be forced to work in a factory. The Constitution of India explicitly prohibits the employment of any child below the age of fourteen years in factories, mines, or other hazardous employment, as outlined in Article 24. Furthermore, Article 23 prohibits all forms of forced labor and traffic in human beings, ensuring children are protected against exploitation.

32. Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part.‚Äî(1) 
The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the

within the local limits of its jurisdiction all or any of the powers exercisable by 
the Supreme Court under clause (2).

otherwise provided for by this Constitution.

evaluation.answer: Yes, based on the comprehensive policy context, being stopped from speaking at a protest is generally against your rights. The policy includes the "Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc." as a fundamental right. These rights, however, can be subject to restrictions or suspension during emergencies, as outlined in the policy's provisions on emergency measures.

evaluation.answer: Based on the Constitution of India's Part III, Fundamental Rights, denying a woman entry to a religious place solely because of her gender may be unconstitutional. Article 15 prohibits discrimination on grounds of sex in access to places of public resort, which could include religious sites if they are maintained by State funds or dedicated to the general public. While religious institutions have the right to manage their own affairs, this right is typically interpreted as being subject to the broader principles of equality enshrined in the Constitution.

Right against Exploitation
23. Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour.‚Äî(1) 
Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are 
prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence 
punishable in accordance with law.
(2) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from imposing 
compulsory service for public purposes, and in imposing such service the State 
shall not make any discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste or 
class or any of them. 
24. Prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc.‚ÄîNo child 
below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or 
mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.
Right to Freedom of Religion
25. Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and 
propagation of religion.‚Äî(1) Subject to public order, morality and health and 
to the other provisions of this Part, all

evaluation.answer: No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. The Constitution of India guarantees the fundamental right to freedom of conscience and the free profession, practice, and propagation of religion, subject only to public order, morality, and health. This freedom includes the right to convert to another religion.

evaluation.answer: When police torture someone in custody, the fundamental right being violated is the 'Protection of life and personal liberty,' as enshrined in Article 21 of the Constitution of India. Torture directly infringes upon a person's personal liberty and can endanger their life, both of which are protected under this crucial fundamental right.

evaluation.answer: Yes, if you are denied admission to a public university because you are from a backward community, the Constitution of India provides avenues for action. It explicitly permits the State to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including in matters of university admission. You can approach the National Commission for Backward Classes, which is empowered to investigate complaints and matters affecting backward classes with the powers of a civil court.
